benchmark_details.name: TREECUT
benchmark_details.overview: TREECUT is a synthetic dataset that generates infinite unanswerable math word problems and their answerable counterparts to evaluate hallucination in large language models.
resources: Dataset generation code will be released upon publication.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the hallucination rates of LLMs on systematically generated unanswerable math word problems.
tasks: Generate unanswerable and answerable math problems
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset is limited to the scope of math word problems and does not cover other areas of mathematics.
out_of_scope_uses: Evaluating datasets outside of the generated structure

data.source: Synthetic generation algorithm described in the paper.

methods: Synthetic problem generation using tree structures.
Prompting LLMs with zero-shot evaluation templates.
methodology.calculation: Hallucination rates are calculated based on model outputs on generated unanswerable problems.
methodology.interpretation: Higher hallucination rates indicate challenges LLMs face in identifying unanswerable problems.
methodology.baseline_results: GPT-4o showed 61% hallucination on unanswerable problems; o3-mini showed 42%.
